Manage users - userbase module

What is this module for?

This module provides a single entry point to manage the user reading preferences for the Read4Me telegram bot.

What classes are there?

  • UserBase - Singleton, for storing the user preferences, serializable.

  • UserPreferences - User reading preferences and other data.

How can you use it?

Note

Each reference of document is intended as a processed instance of the class Doc.

Initialize a UserBase instance using a shared list of topics among users.

userbase = UserBase(topics, topics_descriptions)

user - Add a new user to the userbase or get a specific one.

user: UserPreferences = userbase.user(user_id)

predict_interest() - Score how much a user could be interested in reading a document.

userbase.predict_interest(doc, user_id)

score_custom_topics() - Find which custom topics are most similar to a given document.

userbase.score_custom_topics(doc, user_id)

update_user_preferences() - Update the reading preferences of a user using a document and a score for it.

userbase.update_user_preferences(user_id, doc, vote)

set_topics() - Change the shared topics in the userbase, this will affect all UserPreferences stored in the userbase so that their preferences reflect the new topics.

userbase.set_topics(new_topics, new_topics_descriptions)

Warning

Change in the Word2Vec model is not yet supported and requires manually deleting the bot data and starting over.

class read4me.userbase.UserPreferences(user_id: int, num_topics: int)[source]

This class is a container for the data of a single user. All instances of this class are meant to be stored in a UserBase instance.

The user data is composed of a user id, a user vector and a list of custom topics with a list of their descriptions.

The user_vector is a numpy array with dimensionality equal to the number of topics stored in UserBase.topics. Each weight stored in the user_vector is positionally related to the topics stored in UserBase.topics.

A custom topic is defined by the user at runtime and is generated as a combination of semantic vectors and stored as a numpy array in custom_topics. For each custom topic is also stored its description in custom_topics_descriptions as a string.

Initialize an instance for a new user.

Parameters:

  • user_id – Id of the user.

  • num_topics – Number of topics, defines the number of dimensions for the user vector.

property user_id: int

Get the user id of the current instance.

Returns:

User id.

property user_vector: ndarray[Any, dtype[_ScalarType_co]]
Getter:

Get the user vector.

Setter:

Set the user vector with a new NDArray vector during the learning phase.

Use the setter only when the new vector and the current user vector refer to the same topics. Use replace_user_vector() when the topics have changed and a new vector of preferences needs to be set. Every update to the user vector is intended as a step in learning the user preferences. This method uses a simple forgetting strategy of normalizing the user vector to a length of 5 every 10 updates.

Returns:

User vector.

has_custom_topics() → bool[source]

Return True if the user has custom topics.

Returns:

Boolean.

has_this_custom_topic(topic: ndarray[Any, dtype[_ScalarType_co]]) → bool[source]

Check if the given topic is equal within a numerical tolerance to at least one of the custom topics of the user.

Parameters:

topic – Semantic vector representing a topic.

Returns:

Boolean.

add_custom_topic(topic: ndarray[Any, dtype[_ScalarType_co]], topic_description: str)[source]

Add a custom topic and its description for the current user.

Parameters:

  • topic – Semantic vector of a custom topic.

  • topic_description – Custom topic description.

delete_custom_topic(topic_id: int)[source]

Remove a custom topic and its description from the current user.

The id refers to the position of the topic in the list of custom topics, starting from 0.

Parameters:

topic_id – Position of the custom topic to remove.

delete_all_custom_topics()[source]

Remove all user’s custom topics.

property custom_topics: list[numpy.ndarray[typing.Any, numpy.dtype[+_ScalarType_co]]]

Get the full list of custom topics vectors of the current user.

Returns:

List of NDArray vectors.

property custom_topics_descriptions: list[str]

Get the full list of custom topics descriptions of the current user.

Returns:

List of topics descriptions.

property num_custom_topics: int

Get the number of custom topics of the current user.

Returns:

Number of custom topics of the user.

replace_user_vector(new_vec: ndarray[Any, dtype[_ScalarType_co]])[source]

Replace the user vector with a new vector.

Do not use this method for the learning phase, use the setter user_vector() instead. The new vector can have a different number of dimensions.

Parameters:

new_vec – New user preferences vector.

class read4me.userbase.UserBase(*args, **kwargs)[source]

Singleton class for storing the UserPreferences instances in a dictionary with their user ids as keys. The instance of this class stores the topic vectors and the topics descriptions that are shared by all users, also it performs a prediction of interest of a user in a document and updates the user preferences.

Initialize singleton instance with topics and their descriptions.

Parameters:

  • topics – NDArray vectors of the topics.

  • topics_descriptions – Description of the topics.

property users: dict[int, read4me.userbase.UserPreferences]

Get all the users.

Returns:

Dictionary of users.

property topics: ndarray[Any, dtype[_ScalarType_co]]

Get the shared topic vectors.

Returns:

NDArray vectors.

property topics_descriptions: list[tuple[int, list[tuple[str, float]]]]

Get the list of topics descriptions.

Each topic description has a positional topic id and a list of tuples of the form <word, weight>.

Returns:

List of topics descriptions.

set_topics(new_topics: ndarray[Any, dtype[_ScalarType_co]], new_topics_descriptions: list[tuple[int, list[tuple[str, float]]]])[source]

Set the shared topics of the UserBase. If the current topics and the new topics are different, remap all user’s UserPreferences.user_vector to the new topics.

Parameters:

  • new_topics – New topics for the UserBase.

  • new_topics_descriptions – Descriptions of the new topics.

user(user_id: int) → UserPreferences[source]

Get, or create and get, the user with the specified id.

Parameters:

user_id – The user id.

update_user_preferences(user_id: int, doc: Doc, vote: float)[source]

Update the preferences for a user, based on the vote left for the document.

Parameters:

  • user_id – User id.

  • doc – Processed Doc instance.

  • vote – User’s vote for the document.

predict_interest(doc: Doc, user_id: int) → float[source]

Given a Doc document, compute a prediction score for the interest of the user in the document, the score is a number from -1 to 1.

Parameters:

  • doc – Processed Doc document.

  • user_id – Target user id.

Returns:

Score from -1 to 1.

score_custom_topics(doc: Doc, user_id: int, min_similarity: float = 0.55) → list[tuple[int, str]][source]

For each custom topic of a given user, get the descriptions of the custom topics that are most similar to the document. Return an empty list if there is no match.

Parameters:

  • doc – Doc instance, processed using the custom topics of the user.

  • user_id – Target user id.

  • min_similarity – Lower similarity value.

Returns:

List of tuples, each tuple is a custom topic id with its description.
